Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Mobile Platform for Student Goal-Setting & Engagement
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a platform that leverages Colytix? existing app and user base to create a transformative technology capable of addressing the massive gap in student retention among community college and part-time students. College education is seen as one of the primary drivers of economic success for US citizens and therefore directly impacts on the welfare of citizens and the health of the overall economy. Community colleges received significant attention in 2015 after President Barack Obama proposed to make community college tuition free to many residents of the US in his State of the Union Address. Once implemented, this plan would increase enrollment at community colleges dramatically, but would likely only exacerbate current poor graduation and retention rates if no changes to the status quo are implemented. This project will provide a key technology to help to realize these goals across the country.

An innovative combination of technology, interaction design, and educational theory will be used to enable collaboration between students as well as their faculty and mentors. The ultimate goal of the project is to create an individualized platform that breaks each student?s long term goals down into manageable, short term, individualized targets while providing a community of other students and faculty to monitor progress, provide encouragement, and provide timely and appropriate interventions when necessary. This approach will address all of the key factors in low student retention and provide a clear pathway to success for each individual student. The initial focus of the project will be on science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in community colleges, but the underlying principles of the platform can be applied to any discipline across any geography and/or institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Community colleges are under tapped resources that have the potential to increase our nation’s talents and lower unemployment rates. Unfortunately, only 30 percent of people who begin their higher education at two-year institutions (community colleges) graduate within three years (while only 60 percent who begin their higher education at four-year institutions graduate within six years). These low graduation rates are a direct result of the low year-to-year student retention rates, which show that full-time students at 2-year institutions are retained at only 60% per year (while full-time students at 4-year institutions are generally well-retained at approximately 80-90% per year). Part-time students (except at the most selective 4-year universities) are even more likely to drop out, with only a 40% retention rate. The latest data (collected from 2002 - 2012) show yearly trends which are essentially unchanged. These trends suggest that there is a fundamental failure of the current retention system to address the underlying causes.  


This deficit presents an opportunity for new technology and approaches, specifically tailored to improve retention and success rates. In order to address low retention rates, however, it is critical to understand the underlying causes of low retention. According to a study sponsored by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the root causes of student failure did not relate to the student’s intellectual capacity to complete the work, but instead to what can be referred to as ‘non-cognitive’ factors. It is on these kinds of non-cognitive factors that Colytix focuses most of our resources.


At the same time, significant industry effort has been expended to understand student retention and success by examining data at the end of a class term (and potentially try new approaches for the next cohort of students). In contrast to most of these efforts, Colytix seeks to understand students in real-time and deploy interventions that can improve the outcome of the students who are in need now. To that end, Colytix developed a technology platform to provide students, faculty, and administrators with tools and services for assessing and improving cognitive and non-cognitive factors of current students. With this platform, Colytix is then able to study, design, implement, deploy, validate, and iterate quickly new tools and practices for learning and teaching.


Thus far, using the platform, this project has been able to implement, deploy, and iterate tools based on results of cutting edge research. The platform (server-side) tools include machine learning algorithms, databases, and communication protocols to communicate information among students, instructors, and administrators. The user-facing tools are deployed on smartphones, taking advantage of billions of dollars of technology that students have already purchased and are already familiar. Taken together, these tools are able to measure non-cognitive student metrics, measure student learning and engagement in a class continuously throughout a class term, and synthesize the above information to provide appropriate goals and interventions for each student. Additionally, the machine learning models use the data to reveal potential risk factors that can be used to guide students and faculty towards success.


Interestingly, the underlying platform and concepts are not limited to community colleges. They are likely to be useful for college students across a broad range of institutions and disciplines, including potentially high school students.


Last Modified: 08/08/2018
Modified by: Lori Silverman
